title: 105_s170
content: The "Clone Pager Authorization Act of 1996" may be cited as the Act. It pertains to wire and electronic communications. The "Clone Pager Authorization Act of 1996" amends definitions in title 18, United States Code, regarding communication through a clone pager. It also prohibits the use of a pen register, trap and trace device, or clone pager as defined in the Act. The "Clone Pager Authorization Act of 1996" amends title 18, United States Code to prohibit the use of a pen register, trap and trace device, or clone pager. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT OF CHAPTER 206. Chapter 206 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include clone pagers in addition to trap and trace devices. Chapter 206 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include clone pagers in addition to trap and trace devices. The amendment involves inserting clone pagers alongside trap and trace devices in various sections of the code. The amendment includes adding clone pagers to sections 3121 and 3122 of title 18, United States Code, alongside trap and trace devices. The amendment adds clone pagers to sections 3122 and 3123 of title 18, United States Code, along with trap and trace devices. The amendment adds clone pagers to sections 3122 and 3123 of title 18, United States Code, along with trap and trace devices. The court can authorize the use of a pen register, trap and trace device, or clone pager upon application under section 3122. The amendment allows for the use of a pen register, trap and trace device, or clone pager in criminal investigations if certified as relevant by the Government or law enforcement. The amendment permits the use of a clone pager in criminal investigations, requiring disclosure of subscriber identity or device number. The amendment allows the use of a clone pager in criminal investigations, requiring disclosure of subscriber identity or device number. The amendment permits the use of a clone pager in criminal investigations, necessitating disclosure of subscriber identity or device number. The amendment allows the use of a clone pager in criminal investigations, requiring disclosure of subscriber identity or device number. It includes changes to section 3124, such as adding a clone pager as a device for interception. The amendment allows the use of a clone pager in criminal investigations, with a Federal court able to order a provider of paging service to assist law enforcement officers in using the clone pager. The amendment permits the use of a clone pager in criminal investigations, with a Federal court authorized to compel a paging service provider to aid law enforcement in using the clone pager unobtrusively. The amendment allows the use of a clone pager in criminal investigations, with a Federal court able to compel a paging service provider to assist law enforcement in using the clone pager discreetly. The amendment allows the use of clone pagers in criminal investigations, with a Federal court able to compel a paging service provider to assist law enforcement discreetly. The amendment allows the use of clone pagers in criminal investigations, with a Federal court able to compel a paging service provider to assist law enforcement discreetly. A clone pager is defined as a numeric display device that receives communications intended for another numeric display paging device. The Senate passed the amendment on November 7, 1997.
